conclusion: Analyzing the motion of an electron through metal cylinders in a linear particle accelerator to determine cylinder lengths.
Figure 1 shows metal cylinders arranged in sequence, numbered 0, 1, 2, 3, etc.
Odd-numbered cylinders connect to one pole of an AC power supply, even-numbered cylinders connect to the other pole.
Figure 2 shows the alternating potential difference between poles.
At t = 0, the potential between odd and even cylinders is positive.
Electric field exists in gaps between cylinders but is zero inside cylinders.
Electron starts at rest from plate 0 (even-numbered).
Electron experiences an electric field between plate 0 and cylinder 1, accelerating toward cylinder 1.
Work done on the electron equals its gain in kinetic energy: eU = (1/2)mv_1^2.
Solving for velocity: v_1 = sqrt(2eU/m).
Inside cylinder 1, there is no electric field, electron moves with constant velocity v_1.
Time taken to travel through cylinder 1: t_1 = L_1/v_1 = L_1/sqrt(2eU/m).
For continued acceleration, AC voltage must switch polarity at the right time.
Voltage completes one cycle in time T.
When electron reaches gap between cylinder 1 and 2, voltage must have reversed polarity.
Condition for polarity switch: t_1 = T/2.
Setting transit time equal to half the AC period: L_1/v_1 = T/2.
Substituting value of v_1: L_1/sqrt(2eU/m) = T/2.
Solving for L_1: L_1 = (T/2) sqrt(2eU/m).
As electron exits cylinder 1 and enters gap to cylinder 2, potential difference has reversed.
Electron accelerates again, gaining additional kinetic energy.
New velocity after acceleration: v_2 = sqrt(v_1^2 + 2eU/m) = sqrt(4eU/m).
